title: How was the ship's bilge emptied in the age of sail? - Quora

response.answer_text: They used manual pumps to bring the water up and out of the bilge. During the 1781 Battle of the Capes, which set up the historic and final Siege of Yorktown, one delapidated British ship went into battle even though it was leaking 5 feet of water an hour. (To paraphrase Rumsfeld, “You go to war with the navy you have, not the navy you might want or wish to have at a later time.) It boggles the mind to imagine men furiously pumping the water out while others on deck were firing their cannons at the nearby French ships. Eventually the British ship caught fire from the French onslaught and had to retire from the battle. It was aptly named the Terrible. williamsburgchartersails.com

Normally for the bilge it depends upon the sailing time sea passage, if the sea passage is long, the normal procedure is to clean it with bilge water seperator according to Marpol annd discharge overboard. But other way if frequent ports and short sea passage, add it with sludge and give it to the shore collection facilities.
